segments.en: Linked Discourses 10
1. With Indaka
8. With Sudatta

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati sītavane.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Cool Grove.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati rājagahaṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
segments.en: Now at that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika had arrived at Rājagaha on some business.
He heard
a rumor that a Buddha had arisen in the world.

segments.pli: Tāvadeva ca pana bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitukāmo hoti. Athassa anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa etadahosi:
segments.en: Right away he wanted to go and see the Buddha, but he thought,
“It’s too late to go and see the Buddha today.

segments.pli: Sve dānāhaṃ kālena bhagavantaṃ dassanāya gamissāmī”ti buddhagatāya satiyā nipajji.
segments.en: I’ll go and see him tomorrow.” He went to bed thinking of the Buddha.

segments.pli: Rattiyā sudaṃ tikkhattuṃ vuṭṭhāsi pabhātanti maññamāno.
segments.en: During the night he got up three times thinking it was morning.

segments.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena sivathikadvāraṃ tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then he approached the Sivaka Gate,
and non-human beings opened it for him.

segments.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa nagaramhā nikkhamantassa āloko antaradhāyi, andhakāro pāturahosi, bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso udapādi, tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
segments.en: But as he was leaving the city, light vanished and darkness appeared to him. He felt fear, terror, and goosebumps, and wanted to turn back.

segments.pli: Atha kho sivako yakkho antarahito saddamanussāvesi:
segments.en: Then the invisible spirit Sivaka called out:
“A hundred elephants, a hundred horses,
a hundred mule-drawn chariots,
a hundred thousand maidens
bedecked with jewels and earrings:
these are not worth a sixteenth part
of a single forward stride!
Forward, householder!
Forward, householder!
Going forward is better for you,
not turning back!”

segments.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa andhakāro antaradhāyi, āloko pāturahosi, yaṃ ahosi bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso, so paṭippassambhi.
segments.en: Then darkness vanished and light appeared to Anāthapiṇḍika. His fear, terror, and goosebumps settled down.

segments.pli: Dutiyampi kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa āloko antaradhāyi, andhakāro pāturahosi, bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso udapādi, tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
segments.en: But for a second time, light vanished and darkness appeared to him. …

segments.pli: Dutiyampi kho sivako yakkho antarahito saddamanussāvesi:
segments.en: For a second time the invisible spirit Sivaka called out …
“… Going forward is better for you,
not turning back!”

segments.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa andhakāro antaradhāyi, āloko pāturahosi, yaṃ ahosi bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso, so paṭippassambhi.
segments.en: Then darkness vanished and light appeared to Anāthapiṇḍika. His fear, terror, and goosebumps settled down.

segments.pli: Tatiyampi kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa āloko antaradhāyi, andhakāro pāturahosi, bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso udapādi, tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
segments.en: But for a third time, light vanished and darkness appeared to him. …

segments.pli: Tatiyampi kho sivako yakkho antarahito saddamanussāvesi:
segments.en: For a third time the invisible spirit Sivaka called out …
“… Going forward is better for you,
not turning back!”

segments.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa andhakāro antaradhāyi, āloko pāturahosi, yaṃ ahosi bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso, so paṭippassambhi.
segments.en: Then darkness vanished and light appeared to Anāthapiṇḍika. His fear, terror, and goosebumps settled down.

segments.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena sītavanaṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went to the Cool Grove and approached the Buddha.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya abbhokāse caṅkamati.
segments.en: Now at that time the Buddha had risen at the crack of dawn and was walking meditation in the open.

segments.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
segments.en: He saw Anāthapiṇḍika coming off in the distance.

segments.pli: Disvāna caṅkamā orohitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
segments.en: So he stepped down from the walking path, sat down on the seat spread out,

segments.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: and said to Anāthapiṇḍika,
“Come, Sudatta.”

segments.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati, nāmena maṃ bhagavā ālapatīti, haṭṭho udaggo tattheva bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Anāthapiṇḍika thought, “The Buddha calls me by name!” Smiling and joyful, he bowed with his head to the Buddha’s feet and said to him,
“Sir, I trust the Buddha slept well?”
“A brahmin who is fully extinguished
always sleeps well.
Sensual pleasures slide off them,
they’re cooled, free of attachments.
Since they’ve cut off all clinging,
and removed the stress from the heart,
the peaceful sleep well,
abiding in peace of mind.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha…

suttaplex.blurb: When Anāthapiṇḍika heard that a Buddha had arisen in the world, he rose first thing in the morning to go and visit him. But a mysterious darkness caused him to hesitate, so a spirit repeatedly encouraged him to step forward. Finally he reached the Buddha, and asked if he had slept well.
